image.altText: Glenn Stevens

items.synopsis: Consumer confidence tanks after this month's surprise interest rate rise, as a former Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) governor warns higher inflation and interest rates are here to stay.

title.children: Former RBA boss fears interest rates unlikely to fall in 'once-in-a-generation' battle with inflation

image.altText: A fire truck outside a building that is burnt on the top.

items.synopsis: Multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel in New Zealand's capital, Wellington, authorities have confirmed.

title.children: Fire crews face 'worst nightmare' as multiple people killed in New Zealand hostel blaze

image.altText: Long animal livestock transport truck parked on the side of the road, sunset in the background.

items.synopsis: Truck drivers say smaller vehicles are the leading cause of crashes involving heavy haulage vehicles and that more education is needed.

title.children: Truckies call out 'ridiculous behaviour' of drivers in smaller vehicles amid claims accidents increasing

items.synopsis: Ningaloo's sparkling turquoise waters and marine life are well known to many, but this World Heritage treasure extends to the land, too — and conservationists fear its future is on a knife's edge.

title.children: This wild paradise offers a window into the past and future of our planet

image.altText: A person in all white protective gear treating a big area of black mould on the wall of a house

items.synopsis: Rental properties are more likely be mouldy than other homes and excessive mould growth is known to harm human health. So what can you do about it?

title.children: We're heading in to 'mega mould' season and renters are at greater risk

image.altText: A marine rescue vessel floating in a marina

items.synopsis: A local fisherman who helped rescue two people and recover the body of a third after their boat capsized off the coast of Western Australia says they may have been hit by a freak wave.

title.children: Fisher recounts 'right place, right time' Mother's Day rescue off coast of Geraldton

image.altText: Julia Gillard sitting at a meeting table in a city office and speaking.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Julia Gillard concedes that her desire to have a debate around the merit of marriage in modern society, instead of supporting same-sex marriage itself, was "wrong".

title.children: Gillard says she 'got it incredibly wrong' on same-sex marriage debate

image.altText: A young man in a blue shirt laughing with trees in the background

items.synopsis: Outback Way is famed for being "Australia's longest shortcut", but in recent years its Warakurna Roadhouse has earned its own reputation as a must stop for another reason — dad jokes.

title.children: The jokes are on visitors to this remote WA roadhouse, thanks to its laconic manager

image.altText: Katy, a middle-aged woman in a salmon-pink top, sits at a table looking serious

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

title.children: Australians sell investment properties, refinance mortgages 'at a rate never before seen'

image.altText: Victoria, who has shoulder-length blonde hair, looks calmly at the camera in a close-up portrait.

items.synopsis: On the day former police officer Brett Johnson is sentenced for abusing his position of power to pursue vulnerable women, one of his victims speaks exclusively to the ABC about the devastating impact his offending had on her life.

title.children: A police officer's misconduct shattered Victoria's life. He has today been jailed for six months

image.altText: Looking from behind a diver you see their hand stretched down to the top of the mouth of a whale shark

items.synopsis: In sampling parasites off the lips of whale sharks, scientists have found the world's biggest fish would stop in the water to be cleaned.

title.children: Like hypnotising the world's biggest fish, scientists stop whale sharks in their tracks

image.altText: a woman looking at the camera standing in front of several big bottles of purified water as she hold one bottle

items.synopsis: Reannan Haswell and her Bullsbrook family have had to drink bottled water since 2016 due to contamination from PFAS chemicals. She led a class action that will see 30,000 people receive a payout — but many others will get nothing.

title.children: 'I don't like being wronged': The Perth resident who led the fight for compensation over pollution from toxic foam

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

items.synopsis: An embarrassing day is coming for Australian businesses that have a large gender pay gap, with the data from individual organisations to be made public.

title.children: 'Your gender pay gap is X, why would I go and work for you?': The revealing day coming for Australian businesses

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

items.synopsis: Today marks 80 years since the Dambusters Raid during World War II, a mission so secretive the crew didn't even know their target until the night before.

title.children: The WWII mission from 'hell' that saw pilots fly just above water at 370 kph in enemy territory

image.altText: A composite image of three women. One of the women holds a baby.

items.synopsis: Hopes, dreams, and disappointment. Five women aged between 24 and 41 share their stories of egg freezing.

title.children: Dreams and disappointments: Women share their stories of egg freezing

image.altText: The 'big four'

items.synopsis: Australia's under-pressure banks unveil a new tool to combat scam transactions, but consumer groups say they're still not doing enough to deal with an escalating problem.

title.children: Banks launch new weapon to help recover scam victims' money

image.altText: A graphic showing a corporate headshot of Richard Boyle with redacted cuttings from company documents behind him.

items.synopsis: It's a crisis that calls into question the wisdom of government outsourcing crucial functions and highlights the often cosy relationship between government, bureaucracy, regulators and the corporate world, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: drone shot of beach with turquoise water, rocks, sand, and greenery.

items.synopsis: It's called Denmark but its residents have an Australian accent? Meet the tiny town reaching out to its namesake ahead of the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup in Perth.

title.children: WA town of Denmark invites Princess Mary to visit ahead of FIFA Women's World Cup

image.altText: A child rides a bike on a track with jumps and berms.

items.synopsis: Halls Creek is battling entrenched social issues but leaders say children are flocking to use a new BMX pump track, seen as just the beginning of plans to make the town more liveable.

title.children: 'Stagnated' outback town turns to sport and recreation to drive down youth crime

image.altText: A harvester working a pine plantation

items.synopsis: Farming families in Boyup Brook fear a WA government pitch to grow pine trees in their shire could see the loss of farming businesses with "social and economic consequences".

title.children: Shire's 'grave concern' for farming economy amid WA's pine plantation plan

image.altText: A footpath with bare scorched dunes on the left and burned branches on the right

items.synopsis: Esperance residents are urging beachgoers to protect charcoaled sand dunes left in the wake of a bushfire through one of the region's most popular landscapes.

title.children: Esperance's coastal landscape at risk of erosion following Twilight Beach bushfire

image.altText: A skate lying on the seabed.

items.synopsis: Researchers say Tanya Plibersek's pledge of no new extinctions is under serious threat as the only known population of an endangered ancient Tasmania ray continues to nosedive.

title.children: 'They're just not there': A rare, ancient Australian skate is on thin ice as populations plunge

image.altText: A drago queen with a green and pick hat blowing confetti.

items.synopsis: Betty Confetti's Rainbow Story Time show is intended to promote diversity and inclusion, but it has been called off at a regional NSW library due to safety concerns.

title.children: Drag queen's library show for children cancelled after staff threatened

image.altText: Tight shot of Elon Musk, a white man with short brown hair and brown eyes, wearing a black suit & open-neck white shirt.

items.synopsis: The government of the US Virgin Islands has issued Tesla chief Elon Musk with a court order for documents in its lawsuit that is seeking to hold an American bank, JPMorgan Chase, liable for sex trafficking acts by Jeffrey Epstein.

title.children: US Virgin Islands issues Elon Musk with court order for documents in case against Jeffrey Epstein's bank

image.altText: A logo above a petrol sign reading: "Exxon" in red letters.

items.synopsis: Indonesian villagers — who allege they were subjected to torture, sexual assault, beatings and watching their loved ones being shot by Indonesian soldiers contracted by ExxonMobil in 2001 — agree to a settlement. WARNING: This story contains details some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Exxon Mobil settles Indonesian torture case after more than 20 years

image.altText: A Red Rooster store and a Cold Rock store

items.synopsis: Two Victorian fast-food businesses are hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws, as the state's watchdog cracks down on hospitality and retail franchises.

title.children: Two fast-food businesses hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws

image.altText: A political rally where Cambodian people wear white shirts and wave the Cambodian flag.

items.synopsis: The ruling Cambodian People's Party currently holds every seat in parliament and its strongman leader has said he wants it to dominate politics in the South-East Asian nation for 100 years.

title.children: Cambodia's only credible opposition party disqualified from running in upcoming election

image.altText: An Indigenous woman smiles at the camera with shrubs behind her

items.synopsis: Billions of dollars is poured into mining in remote Australia, so why don't the lights stay on in nearby communities?

title.children: First Nations leaders want to ensure remote communities are not left behind with renewable energy expansion

image.altText: Ukrainian service members from a 3rd separate assault brigade of the Armed Forces of Ukraine.

items.synopsis: While the UK prime minister says his country alone cannot supply Ukraine with fighter jets, he pledges to support Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the creation of a "jets coalition" between allies.

title.children: Ukraine claims battlefield gains in Bakhmut as Zelenskky's Europe tour secures more weapons

image.altText: A woman

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives have revisited the investigation into the death of Healesville woman Marea Yann in 2003. A $1 million reward for information is being offered.

title.children: Marea was killed 'in the place she should have felt safest'. Decades later, police are offering a $1m reward

image.altText: A man stands in front of red and green indicator boards.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market has begun its day lower, after modest overnight gains on Wall Street amid concerns about a slowing US economy and wavering optimism over a debt ceiling deal in Washington.

title.children: ASX slips, Wall Street rises as US debt ceiling debate drags on

liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market snapshot at 12:42pm AEST

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 is trading lower, down 0.2 per cent to 7,254. Nine of 11 sectors are in the red. Materials is the best performing sector. Here's a look at stocks with the biggest gains and declines:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX down, as consumer staples, health and tech drag

children.content: is trading lower, down 0.2 per cent to 7,254.
Nine of 11 sectors are in the red. Materials is the best performing sector.
Here's a look at stocks with the biggest gains and declines:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ABC News business reporter David Taylor's had a look at the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute Consumer Sentiment report. Here's his take on it: ‘Dismal’ is the word Westpac has used to describe how many consumers or households feel at present. The latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute Consumer Sentiment measure for May fell 7.9 per cent. “The Melbourne Institute of Consumer Sentiment index fell by 7.9 per cent, from 85.8 in April to 79.0 in May,” Westpac Chief Economist, Bill Evans said. “The Index has fallen back to just above the dismal levels seen back in March, which recorded the lowest monthly read since the COVID outbreak in 2020 and, before that, since the deep recession of the early 1990s.” “The two key developments over the last month have been the surprise decision by the Reserve Bank Board to lift the cash rate by a further 0.25% in May and the Federal Budget.” The bank reports the sharpest drop in sentiment are among those on low incomes, renters, mortgagors and women. Interestingly, the crisis of confidence among renters is greater than those with a mortgage, despite the interest rate hikes. Most households expect interest rates to keep rising more here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dismal days for consumer sentiment

children.content: ABC News business reporter David Taylor's
had a look at the latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute Consumer Sentiment report. Here's his take on it:
‘Dismal’ is the word Westpac has used to describe how many consumers or households feel at present.
The latest Westpac-Melbourne Institute Consumer Sentiment measure for May fell 7.9 per cent.
“The Melbourne Institute of Consumer Sentiment index fell by 7.9 per cent, from 85.8 in April to 79.0 in May,” Westpac Chief Economist, Bill Evans said.

“The Index has fallen back to just above the dismal levels seen back in March, which recorded the lowest monthly read since the COVID outbreak in 2020 and, before that, since the deep recession of the early 1990s.”
“The two key developments over the last month have been the surprise decision by the Reserve Bank Board to lift the cash rate by a further 0.25% in May and the Federal Budget.”
The bank reports the sharpest drop in sentiment are among those on low incomes, renters, mortgagors and women.
Interestingly, the crisis of confidence among renters is greater than those with a mortgage, despite the interest rate hikes.
Most households expect interest rates to keep rising more here.

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: The FBI lacked evidence to investigate Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and relied too heavily on tips provided by Mr Trump's political opponents to fuel the probe, US Special Counsel John Durham concluded in a report released on Monday.

title.children: FBI lacked evidence for alleged Trump-Russia collusion probe, US Special Counsel finds

image.altText: Man wearing a suit, standing next to a window.

items.synopsis: Following the release of the damning Brereton report in November 2020, Defence confirmed Army had "initiated administrative action against 17 individuals where there was an alleged failure to meet ADF expectations".

title.children: Defence insists due process was given to accused soldiers as anger grows over Afghanistan inquiry fallout

image.altText: Thailand elections

items.synopsis: After the weekend's national election, Thailand's two main opposition parties agree to form a ruling coalition after they trounced the military-backed rivals that have controlled government for nearly a decade.

title.children: Thailand opposition parties agree to coalition as poll winner Move Forward cheered in by voters

image.altText: A collection of Chiang Kai-shek statues lumped together in a park

items.synopsis: Taiwan is littered with monuments to one of its most divisive leaders. However, as efforts to remove them stall, some activists to are taking matters into their own hands.

title.children: Statues of a 'ruthless' dictator are all over Taiwan. His critics keep dumping them in this park
